lecture.title: Multiplayer games with WebXR
lecture.label: Frontend
lecture.description: Virtual Reality is a technology used for building realistic experiences for games, environments, content display as well as marketing. In this session, I will teach the participants about 3D objects in the web, virtual reality, VR devices, WebVR, WebVR API and finally building games with A-Frame. In this talk, I will also showcase creating a multiplayer game similar to Pokemon Go using WebXR in a live coding session. The live coding session will cover topics such as creating the game scene, importing 3D objects, interaction with objects, adding animations, implementing WebAR and adding multiplayer capability to the game with real time databases. By the end of the session, the participants will have a complete understanding of what WebXR is and they will be able to create cross-browser WebXR experiences as well as multiplayer games similar to Pokemon Go.

lecture.title: Breaking news: A web performance story
lecture.label: Frontend
lecture.description: At the Financial Times we built one of the world's fastest news websites. This talk sheds light on the unique challenges of optimising web performance for a highly componentised micro frontends architecture with a rapid release cycle and a common toolchain that punishes dissent. Weâ€™ll explore how we deliver and build ft.com, along with the underlying architectural and organisational decisions and their implications to high availability, high reliability, and optimal performance. This is an opportunity to learn about the payoffs and trade-offs we made along the way, and what the future holds.

lecture.title: Delivering Fast and Beautiful Images and Video
lecture.label: Frontend
lecture.description: The average mobile website page weight is ~50% images. Toss in the complication of thousands of differently sized screens, and it might appear that efficient delivery of images to every device is an impossible task. But all is not lost! In this talk, weâ€™ll examine strategies to send the perfect image to every device, ensuring a fast, beautiful rendering of your content. Weâ€™ll look at progressive images, placeholder images, lazy loading and other techniques and real world examples that will improve the usability of your site or app. Attendees will come away with an understand of the current â€˜state of the artâ€™ for optimizing visual content on the web.

lecture.title: There once was Swift
lecture.label: Common
lecture.description: We live with Swift in a fifth version of which we are promised to have the stability of the binary interface and happiness. But how can we use all these exciting things for greater good? One can program differently and it is not clear which way is the right one. How to know where the pitfalls are? Why are they there? And are these real pitfalls or just imaginary? Lets take a look together.
